Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a time-resolved nanophotonic scanning probe microscope for the in situ characterization of materials for energy and sustainability
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) program, Professor Isabell Thommann from the William Marsh Rice University will acquire parts to asssemble a femtosecond time-resolved nanophotonic scanning probe microscope. This will make it possible to study nanostructured materials synthesized for energy and sustainability applications with unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution. These measurements will allow probing the chemical and physical properties of the materials to help understand energy flow and charge carrier dynamics in hybrid nanostructured materials. This will help to address challenges in the production of large scale applications of these materials. The acquisition will be a multiuser instrument used by researchers at the university and also for new collaborations in the Houston area, and nationally. It will strengthen the outreach efforts at the university to high school teachers and students.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) studying charge separation kinetics in all-conjugated block copolymer thin films; (b) investigating carrier dynamics in two-dimensional materials and devices for energy; (c) using time-resolved photoluminescence as a probe of hot electron dynamics; (d) studying hot electron dynamics in plasmonic antennas; (e) carrying out spatiotemporal investigations of photocatalytic virus inactivation; (f) studying photocatalytic water splitting on nanostructured cobalt oxide by time-resolved tip-enhanced Raman scattering; (g) investigating photocatalytic water splitting on plasmonic photoelectrodes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goals:

Nanoscale material platforms such as plasmonic structures, 2D materials, metamaterials enable the realization of counterintuitive optical phenomena and serve as ideal platforms to study and control several physiochemical processes such as absorption, Raman scattering, photocatalysis, etc. Techniques such as atomic force microscopy and scanning electron microscopy provide information about the material morphology and topography at the nanoscale, while other techniques such as scanning near-field optical microscopy, enable the characterization of near-field optical properties of such designer optical materials. However, the task of imaging nanoscale building blocks and understanding their optical response is limited by spatial and temporal resolution, imaging sensitivity or practicality. Our objective here was to work with a new imaging technique called photo-induced force microscopy, which enables topographical imaging and the characterization of optical response of nanoscale materials, simultaneously, with very high spatiotemporal resolutions.

Intellectual merit:

We developed and built a phto-induced force microscope. This is the first of its kind instrument. To demonstrate the instrument we showed the efficacy of photoinduced force microscopy in evaluating local field variations in plasmonic materials. We showed that the enhancement of near-field optical forces in plasmonic gold nanorods and disk dimers are polarization sensitive and correlate well with expected field enhancements.  We complemented our experimental studies with calculations, by introducing a new way to evaluate the optical forces in such plasmonic materials, enabling us to model realistic geometries of the tip and sample. In a different set of experiments, we detected the mutual interactions (hybridization) between gold and aluminium discs in heterodimer structures separated by nanoscale gaps, by measuring the optical force spectra in individual discs and comparing them to far-field extinction measurements. We also inferred that the measured force spectra effectively track near-field absorption profiles in such complex plasmonic structures.

The project provided the opportunity for training a postdoctoral researcher in the new technique and in building the microscope. The results of the project have been published in Nano Letters (2016) and another manuscript is under preparation. The results were also presented at several national and international conferences.

Broader impact

We believe that photoinduced force mapping will be a valuable addition to the toolbox of existing techniques for near-field imaging and characterization, furthering the ability to study fundamental physical and chemical phenomena with very high spatiotemporal resolutions. More importantly, the ability to perform near-field imaging, spectroscopy, topographical mapping and characterization, all simultaneously, will aid efforts of integrating nano-optical materials into nanoscale devices for chemical, biological and materials applications.
